key_work.title: Jedda
key_work.credit_line:
Courtesy Chauvel Film Enterprises Pty Ltd

Jedda is held in the collection of the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
key_work.brief_description: Jedda is beloved by many First Peoples for being Australia’s first film with Aboriginal lead roles. But despite being a first for First Peoples representation, it also reflects deeply problematic times in Australia, characterised by policies of assimilation and forced removel of Indigenous children.

constellations_primary.name: Jedda: Uneven ground, the road to on-screen diversity
constellations_primary.description: Jedda was the first fully funded Australian feature to be shot on colour film. It was also the first Australian film with Aboriginal actors in lead roles, however, it reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history.

end.title: Australian Walkabout
end.brief_description: Australian Walkabout is a TV series made for the ABC and BBC by director Charles Chauvel. It was the last project completed by Chauvel prior to his death.

links.description: Three years after Jedda, Charles and Elsa Chauvel produced this popular 13-part TV outback travelogue for the BBC.

end.title: Night Cries: A Rural Tragedy
end.brief_description: Tracey Moffat’s artwork that acts as an unofficial sequel to Jedda and reframes the story through an Indigenous lens.

links.description: Artist Tracey Moffat reworked elements of Jedda in response to Charles Chauvel’s film. Night Cries imagines the future of a character like Jedda – an Aboriginal child adopted by a white woman – caring for the white woman at the end of her life.

end.title: Q&A
end.brief_description: Hosted by Hamish Macdonald, Q&A puts punters, pollies and pundits together in the studio to thrash out the hot issues of the week. It’s about democracy in action - the audience gets to ask the questions.

links.description: While the depiction of First Peoples in Jedda reflects colonial views of the times, actor Rosalie Kunoth-Monks was inspired to become an activist by the experience. She made a memorable Q&A appearance, where she declared “Don’t try and suppress me and don’t call me a problem, I am not the problem.”
